profileText: A Representative from Missouri; born in Windsor, near Fredericksburg, Va., November 1, 1817; received a limited schooling; studied law; was admitted to the bar and commenced practice in Bowling Green, Mo.; elected as a Whig to the Thirty-second Congress (March 4, 1851-March 3, 1853); unsuccessful candidate for reelection in 1852 to the Thirty-third Congress; elected as an Opposition Party candidate to the Thirty-fourth Congress (March 4, 1855-March 3, 1857); chairman, Committee on Private Land Claims (Thirty-fourth Congress); circuit judge 1866-1880; resumed the practice of law; died in Hannibal, Marion County, Mo., November 1, 1894; interment in Riverside Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Porter, Gilchrist. Remarks of Hon. G. Porter, of Missouri, on the organization of the House of Representatives. Washington: Printed at the Congressional Globe Office, 1856.

researchRecord.name: 1858, 1 item.
researchRecord.description: A letter from James O. Broadhead to J.S. Black written on June 30, 1858. In the letter, James O. Broadhead recommends H. Clay Ewing as U.S. District Attorney for the Western district of Missouri. The letter is also signed by G. Porter and Thomas S. Miller.

recordLocation.name: Department of Literary and Historical Manuscripts
